facts.text: The appeal arises from the judgment and decree dated 28th February 1945 of the High Court of Nagpur upholding the dismissal of the suit by the First Additional District Judge Nagpur on 30th June 1938.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from the judgment and decree dated 28th February, 1945, of the High Court of Nagpur upholding the dismissal of the suit by the First Additional District Judge, Nagpur, on 30th June, 1938.

facts.text: Certificate for leave to appeal to this Court was granted on 23rd February 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate for leave to appeal to this Court was granted on 23rd February, 1951.

facts.text: P. B. Deshmukh deceased represented by legal representatives and S. B. Deshmukh both cousins formed a joint Hindu family of which P. B. Deshmukh was the manager.

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Deshmukh, deceased,  number represented on record by his legal representatives  and S. B. Deshmukh, both companysins, formed a joint Hindu family of which the former was the manager.

facts.text: S. B. Deshmukh managed money-lending shops at Kelod and Rejegaon while P. B. Deshmukh managed the shop at Badegaon.

anchor.surface_text: For facility of the management of business S. B. Deshmukh managed money-ending shops at Kelod and Rejegaon, while P. B. Deshmukh managed the shop at Badegaon.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer Nagpur issued notice under section 22 sub-section 2 of the Income tax Act on 1st April 1930 against the three shops calling for return of total income of joint family during 1928-29.

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st of April, 1930, the Income-tax Officer Nagpur, issued a numberice under section 22, sub-section  2 , of the Income tax Act against the three shops of the firm calling for the return of the total income of the joint family during 1928-29.

facts.text: M. K. Hirde who held general power of attorney from the two cousins filed return on 3rd July 1930 signed and verified by him as agent.

anchor.surface_text: On the 3rd July, 1930, M. K. Hirde, who held a general power of attorney from the two companysins, filed a return which was signed and verified by him as agent.

facts.text: Pursuant to notice under section 23(2) account books for 1924-29 produced and P. B. Deshmukh examined on oath by Income-tax Officer on 23rd November 1930 regarding omissions in return.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to a numberice issued under section 23  2  by the Income-tax Officer, the account books of the firm for 1924-29 were produced and P. B. Deshmukh was examined on oath by the Income-tax Officer on the 23rd November, 1930, in respect of certain omissions in the return.

facts.text: P. B. Deshmukh explained omissions of Rs. 7231 as from personal funds not joint family and Rs. 30477 repayments due to mistake of dismissed agent Raghunath Choudhary.

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Deshmukh explained that the omissions of an item of Rs. 7,231 was due to the fact that it was advanced from his own personal funds and had numberhing to do with the joint family, while the omissions of other items of repayment amounting to Rs. 30,477 by the debtors were due to the mistake of his agent, one Raghunath Choudhary, who had been dismissed since 1929.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer not satisfied with explanation recommended P. B. Deshmukh's prosecution and Assistant Commissioner issued notice to show cause why prosecution should not be sanctioned.

anchor.surface_text: Not being satisfied with his explanation, the Income-tax Officer recommended P. B. Deshmukhs prosecution and the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax issued numberice to him to show cause why his prosecution in respect of these omissions should number be sanctioned.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner examined P. B. Deshmukh on 13th December 1930 when he admitted concealing income of over Rs. 30000.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner examined P. B. Deshmukh on 13th December, 1930, when he admitted that he had companycealed income of over Rs. 30,000.

facts.text: P. B. Deshmukh was told he would be prosecuted under section 52 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: He was told that he would be prosecuted under section 52 of the Act.

facts.text: P. B. Deshmukh proposed compounding the offence under section 53 upon payment of Rs. 30000 which was agreed by Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the discussion which followed, P. B. Deshmukh proposed that the offence should be companypounded under section 53 upon payment by him of Rs. 30,000 to the taxing authorities and this was agreed to by the Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Payment of Rs. 30000 made in two instalments and matter closed.

anchor.surface_text: The payment was made in two instalments and the matter was closed.

facts.text: In January 1934 the two cousins filed suit for recovery of Rs. 30000 and Rs. 5331-1-3 interest against Secretary of State for India in Council.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1934, the two companysins filed a suit for recovery of Rs. 30,000 and Rs. 5,331-1-3 as interest, against the Secretary of State for India in Council.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed P. B. Deshmukh's statement of 13th December 1930 was incorrectly recorded and Rs. 30000 extorted under threat of proceedings without jurisdiction and no offence committed.

anchor.surface_text: The ground of the claim was that P. B. Deshmukhs statement of 13th December, 1930, was incorrectly recorded and that the sum of Rs. 30,000 was extorted from him under a threat of legal proceedings which were without jurisdiction and that he had companymitted numberoffence.

facts.text: Plaintiffs reiterated omission due to mistake of agent.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that the omission was due to the mistake of the agent was reiterated.

facts.text: Defence pleaded statements of 23rd November and 13th December 1930 correctly recorded proposal for compounding from P. B. Deshmukh after consulting counsel no coercion agent competent and aware of omissions.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted and it was pleased in defence that both the statements of P. B. Deshmukh dated 23rd November, and 13th December, 1930, were companyrectly recorded, that the proposal for companypounding the offence on payment of Rs. 30,000 emanated from P. B. Deshmukh himself after he had companysulted his companynsel and that there was numbercoercion exercised on him in companypounding the offence.

facts.text: Trial Court held statements by P. B. Deshmukh before Income-tax authority correct record voluntarily offered Rs. 30000 owning mistakes not compelled to compound.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court framed issues embodying the companytroversy between the parties, and, after a careful companysideration of the entire evidence, held that the statements made by P. B. Deshmukh before the Income-tax authority represented a companyrect record of facts that he voluntarily offered to pay Rs. 30,000 by owning his mistakes and that he was number companypelled to agree to the companyposition of the offence upon payment of Rs. 30,000.

facts.text: Trial Court held agent competent to sign and verify returns and P. B. Deshmukh liable to prosecution under section 107 read with section 177 Indian Penal Code dismissed claim.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court also held that the agent who held the general power of attorney from P. B. Deshmukh was companypetent to sign and verify the income-tax returns and that the latter was liable to prosecution under section 107 read with section 177, Indian Penal Code. Upon these findings the claim was dismissed.

facts.text: High Court upheld statements of 23rd November and 13th December 1930 authentic record.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal upheld the finding that the two statements of 23rd November and 13th December, 1930, were an authentic record of the statement of P. B. Deshmukh.

facts.text: High Court found P. B. Deshmukh experienced businessman and honorary magistrate made voluntary offer to compound after consulting adviser knowing liable under section 52.

anchor.surface_text: It further found that P. B. Deshmukh was an experienced businessman and an honorary magistrate and that he made a voluntary offer to companypound the offence after companysulting his legal adviser knowing fully well that he was at fault and was liable to be prosecuted under section 52 of the Act.

facts.text: High Court held P. B. Deshmukh bound by agent liable under section 52 or as abettor dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that P. B. Deshmukh was bound by the action of his agent and was liable under section 52 but even if he was number liable as a principal but only as an abettor that was a question for the criminal companyrt to decide. In the result the appeal was dismissed.

issues.text: Whether P. B. Deshmukh was liable to be prosecuted under section 52 of the Income Tax Act given that the return was signed and verified by his agent holding a power of attorney

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal was dismissed. Upon the concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below no question of law arises. It is, however, contended on the authority of Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, Bengal v. Shri Keshab Chandra Mandal that under the law the return of income must be signed by the individual personally and not by his agent even if he holds a power of attorney and it is urged that P. B. Deshmukh was not liable for the act of his agent and could not be prosecuted for the false statement in the return under section 52 of the Income tax Act. This contention has no force.

issues.text: Whether section 53 of the Income Tax Act permits compounding of offences under sections 51 or 52 without proof that the offence was actually committed

anchor.surface_text: What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.

issues.text: Whether the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax was competent to accept the offer to compound the offence under section 53

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Deshmukh being anxious to avoid his liability for prosecution made a voluntary offer to compound the offence which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax was fully competent to accept under section 53 of the Act. The offer was made obviously to avert the disgrace and ignominy of a prosecution.

issues.text: Whether P. B. Deshmukh was liable under section 51(c) of the Income Tax Act for failing to furnish a return under section 22(2) despite notice
Whether the authority to compound under section 53 applies regardless of whether the liability is under section 51 or section 52
Whether a criminal court could alter a charge from section 52 to section 51(c) of the Income Tax Act
Whether concurrent findings of fact by the courts below raise any question of law warranting interference

anchor.surface_text: Upon the concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below no question of law arises.

arguments.claim: section 53 permits compounding of offences under s51 or s52 without proof that offence was actually committed

anchor.surface_text: What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.

holdings.text: Upon the concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below no question of law arises.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below no question of law arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts concurrently found statements authentic, offer voluntary, and no coercion, precluding interference absent legal error.

holdings.text: P. B. Deshmukh was liable to prosecution under section 52 notwithstanding the income return being signed by agent holding power of attorney; contention that personal signature required to establish liability has no force.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, contended on the authority of Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, Bengal v. Shri Keshab Chandra Mandal that under the law the return of income must be signed by the individual personally and not by his agent even if he holds a power of attorney and it is urged that P. B. Deshmukh was not liable for the act of his agent and could not be prosecuted for the false statement in the return under section 52 of the Income tax Act. This contention has no force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's reliance on precedent distinguishing personal verification requirement as not barring principal's liability or compounding.

holdings.text: Section 53 permits Inspecting Assistant Commissioner to compound offence under section 51 or 52 before or after proceedings without proof that offence was actually committed.

anchor.surface_text: What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s53 imposes no proof requirement for compounding.

holdings.text: Any proceeding on charge under section 51 or 52 falls within purview of section 53 permitting compounding.

anchor.surface_text: If there is a proceeding on a charge under section 51 or section 52, it comes within the purview of section 53 and a compounding of the offence will be quite within the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s53 to potential proceedings under covered sections.

holdings.text: Assistant Commissioner competent to accept voluntary offer to compound under section 53.

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Deshmukh being anxious to avoid his liability for prosecution made a voluntary offer to compound the offence which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax was fully competent to accept under section 53 of the Act. The offer was made obviously to avert the disgrace and ignominy of a prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluntary offer by assessee to avoid prosecution within authority conferred by s53.

holdings.text: Even assuming no liability under section 52 due to agent verification, liability subsists under section 51(c) for failure without reasonable cause to furnish return under section 22(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical alternative liability via non-furnishing despite notice.

holdings.text: Authority to compound under section 53 unaffected by whether underlying liability under section 51(c) or section 52; section 53 covers both.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S53 explicitly encompasses offences under either section without distinction.

holdings.text: P. B. Deshmukh prosecutable under section 51(c) or 52; criminal court may alter charge from section 52 to 51(c).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative charges available; courts possess power to amend charges procedurally.

anchor.surface_text: What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.
